title: AB 15
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 52.5 of the Civil Code is amended to allow victims of human trafficking to bring civil actions for damages, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees. Plaintiffs may be awarded up to three times their actual damages or $10,000, whichever is greater, and punitive damages if malice, oppression, fraud, or duress is proven. An action under this section must be filed within seven years of the victim being freed from trafficking, or within 10 years after a minor victim reaches the age of majority. Disability, such as being a minor or lacking legal capacity, will pause the statute of limitations for the action. The statute of limitations is paused for minors or those lacking legal capacity, even if a guardian ad litem is appointed. A defendant cannot use the statute of limitations defense if their actions caused the delay in filing. The suspension of the statute of limitations also applies to related claims in trafficking cases. The statute of limitations is postponed during criminal proceedings against the victim. The running of the statute of limitations may be suspended for those unable to discover the cause of action due to trafficking circumstances. A prevailing plaintiff can receive attorney's fees and restitution paid by the defendant will be credited against any judgment obtained. A civil action filed under this section shall be stayed during any criminal action related to the same incident. A new section is added to the Code of Civil Procedure, stating that actions for assault, battery, or similar crimes must be initiated within 10 years. This includes acts of torture, genocide, and war crimes. The curr_chunk discusses various acts considered as crimes against humanity, including murder, enslavement, rape, persecution, and other inhuman acts causing great suffering. These acts are part of a widespread or systematic attack on a civil population. An action for wrongful death or property violation under international law, including insurance claims related to the described conduct. An action brought under this section for wrongful death or property violation under international law shall not be dismissed for failure to comply with any previously applicable statute of limitations. Section 361 does not apply if the unlawful act occurred in the state. A prevailing plaintiff may receive attorney’s fees and litigation costs. This section applies to actions starting from January 1, 2016, and its provisions are severable.
